Verso: June 11, 1949 Ohio Wesleyan University

Note: While the 100 86-year-old Bishop (Hunt[?] Welch) makes a long speech inducting Arthur Flemming into the office of Chancellor at Ohio Wesleyan University, in the background three have fallen sound asleep -- on the left retiring Chancellor - Dr. Burgstahler, President Herbert Hoover and L.T.
Walter Hagen, who some golf experts believe to have been the greatest golfer of all time.

Injured Newscaster Returns with Message fro Truman New York Noted author and newscaster Lowell Thomas (center), who was injured when he was thrown by a horse on a Tibetian mountain pass, is shown being greeted by his father, Dr. Harry C. Thomas

Verso: Injured Newscaster Returns with Message fro Truman New York Noted author and newscaster Lowell Thomas (center), who was injured when he was thrown by a horse on a Tibetian mountain pass, is shown being greeted by his father, Dr. Harry C. Thomas, on his arrival, with his son, Lowell, Jr. (left), at LaGuardia Airport today. Thomas told newsmen that after his injury, he was carried for 16 days and nights by native bearers to a town where he could recieve medical aid. Although his injury has been diagnosed as a broken thigh bone, he is able to walk on crutches. Also, Thomas is carrying a personal message from the Tibetian government to President Truman along with an official scroll from the Dalai Lama, the boy ruler of the inaccessible nation. Thomas is believed the first westerner in history to be given such a message from the religious rulers of Tibet. MCS 10/16/49
Note: [envelope] We return from Tibet, and are met by my father

December 21, 1942 - Stricken Japanese Cargo Ships - Four plumes of smoke, one just barely discernible on the horizon near the tip of the island in the background, arise from as many Japanese cargo vessels destroyed by U.S. forces in the Battle of Guadalcanal. The vessels were found beached at Tassafaronga, about 7 1/2 miles west of U.S. positions on Guadalcanal November 15, 1942 and were destroyed by bombs, artillery and naval gun fire. In addition the enemy lost 11 warships, including one battleship, and eight transports and suffered damage to seven other wasships. American losses in the battle were two light cruisers and six destroyers.

Verso: December 21, 1942 - Stricken Japanese Cargo Ships - Four plumes of smoke, one just barely discernible on the horizon near the tip of the island in the background, arise from as many Japanese cargo vessels destroyed by U.S. forces in the Battle of Guadalcanal. The vessels were found beached at Tassafaronga, about 7 1/2 miles west of U.S. positions on Guadalcanal November 15, 1942 and were destroyed by bombs, artillery and naval gun fire. In addition the enemy lost 11 warships, including one battleship, and eight transports and suffered damage to seven other wasships. American losses in the battle were two light cruisers and six destroyers.

December 28, 1942 - Japanese transports, hit by U.S. surface ships and aircraft, are seen beached and burning at Tassafaronge, seven and one half miles from American positions on Guadalcanal, on November 16, 1942. They were the only ships to reach the island of a powerful Japanese fleet which attempted a mass attack on Guadalcanal, but which was crushed in the fleet actions of Nov. 12-15.

Verso: December 28, 1942 - Japanese transports, hit by U.S. surface ships and aircraft, are seen beached and burning at Tassafaronge, seven and one half miles from American positions on Guadalcanal, on November 16, 1942. They were the only ships to reach the island of a powerful Japanese fleet which attempted a mass attack on Guadalcanal, but which was crushed in the fleet actions of Nov. 12-15.

An American task force is shown while being attached from the air in the Battle of Santa Cruz, Oct. 26, 1942. A Carrier on the right is sharply turning. The U.S. destroyer SMITH (center) has just been struck by a burning, falling Japanese plane. On the left two screening vessels are seen.

Verso: An American task force is shown while being attached from the air in the Battle of Santa Cruz, Oct. 26, 1942. A Carrier on the right is sharply turning. The U.S. destroyer SMITH (center) has just been struck by a burning, falling Japanese plane. On the left two screening vessels are seen.

1. Lieutenant Harold H. (Swede) Larsen, commander of the Navy's famous Torpedo Squadron Eight, has been on Pacific duty since before Pearl Harbor. His squadron has just completed four months active duty off Guadalcanal during which only one plane was lost in 27 attacks on Nipponese ships and positions. The ribbons on his breast include those of the Navy Cross and the Distinguished Flying Cross."

The ribbons on his breast include those of the Navy Cross and the Distinguished Flying Cross."

Only Navy Nurse to Escape from Corregidor - Miss Ann Agnes Bernatitus, USNNC, the only Navy nurse to escape from Bataan and the siege of Corregidor, left the Manila Bay fortress on a submarine two days before the surrender. She returned to this country only a few days ago.

Verso: Only Navy Nurse to Escape from Corregidor - Miss Ann Agnes Bernatitus, USNNC, the only Navy nurse to escape from Bataan and the siege of Corregidor, left the Manila Bay fortress on a submarine two days before the surrender. She returned to this country only a few days ago.

January 2, 1943 - This is machinist Donald E. Runyon, USN, of Fighting Squadron Six, who shot down eight Japanese planes in aerial combat during the month of August, 1942. He bagged four of the planes in a single day. Runyon lives in Ellisville, Miss.

December 1, 1942 - (h) Casablanca, French Morocco - Two French destroyers (foreground) and a light French cruiser beached north of Casablanca Harbor.
Verso: December 1, 1942 - (h) Casablanca, French Morocco - Two French destroyers (foreground) and a light French cruiser beached north of Casablanca Harbor.

December 1, 1942 - (c) Casablanca, French Morocco - On the morning after the first attack this aerial reconnaissance photo was taken from a U.S. Navy plane. It shows five burning French ships in the various harbors of Casablanca. One can be seen burnign at the end of the large pier (top). Theother four are in the outer harbor, ranging from center to left, and the extreme lower left corner. At the end of the large pier, the French merchantship Porthos can be seen lying on its side.

Verso: December 1, 1942 - (c) Casablanca, French Morocco - On the morning after the first attack this aerial reconnaissance photo was taken from a U.S. Navy plane. It shows five burning French ships in the various harbors of Casablanca. One can be seen burnign at the end of the large pier (top). Theother four are in the outer harbor, ranging from center to left, and the extreme lower left corner. At the end of the large pier, the French merchantship Porthos can be seen lying on its side.

December 1, 1942 - (d) Casablanca, French Morocco - A closeup view from the starboard side of the unfinished French battleship, Jean Bart, discloses damage near the bow and near the stern. Note also the shade and pier damaged as the result of bombing and shell fire from U. S. Fleet.

Verso: December 1, 1942 - (d) Casablanca, French Morocco - A closeup view from the starboard side of the unfinished French battleship, Jean Bart, discloses damage near the bow and near the stern. Note also the shade and pier damaged as the result of bombing and shell fire from U. S. Fleet.

September, 1942 - HIT--Periscope photograph made by Pacific Fleet Submarine shows big Japanese freighter (not the case as in accompanying picture) broken in two after torpedoing in enemy homeland waters, and sinking.

Verso: September, 1942 - HIT--Periscope photograph made by Pacific Fleet Submarine shows big Japanese freighter (not the case as in accompanying picture) broken in two after torpedoing in enemy homeland waters, and sinking.

An American Sub's Eye View of Sinking of a Japanese Destroyer: This remarkable photograph, the first combat action photograph taken through the periscope of an American submarine, shows and enemy destroyer of one of the latest and largest types after it had been struck by two torpedoes launched by the submarine from which the picture was taken. The destroyer sank in nine minutes. Note the Rising Sin insignia on top of the turret to the left, ehich serves as an identification mark for aircraft. Also note the two men in white scrambling over the conning tower to the right. The marks on the left and the center line are etchings on the periscope.

Verso: An American Sub's Eye View of Sinking of a Japanese Destroyer: This remarkable photograph, the first combat action photograph taken through the periscope of an American submarine, shows and enemy destroyer of one of the latest and largest types after it had been struck by two torpedoes launched by the submarine from which the picture was taken. The destroyer sank in nine minutes. Note the Rising Sin insignia on top of the turret to the left, ehich serves as an identification mark for aircraft. Also note the two men in white scrambling over the conning tower to the right. The marks on the left and the center line are etchings on the periscope.

November 6, 1942 - Remnant of a Rising Sun Bomber -- This wing section was the largest single piece remaining of a Japanese bomber after its bomb load was touched off by a U.S. Marine anti-aircraft shell at 20,000 feet. The plane disintegrated in the sky, bits raining down over a wide area.

Verso: November 6, 1942 - Remnant of a Rising Sun Bomber -- This wing section was the largest single piece remaining of a Japanese bomber after its bomb load was touched off by a U.S. Marine anti-aircraft shell at 20,000 feet. The plane disintegrated in the sky, bits raining down over a wide area.

December 2, 1942 - USS Oklahoma: Rescue crews are shown here working on the upturned hull of the 29,000-ton battleship USS Oklahoma, which capsised in Pearl Harbor after being blasted by Japanese warplanes. Holes were burned through the hull to permit the rescue of some of the men trapped below. Note one of the Oklahoma'S launches in the foreground. The battleship, USS Marylandis in the background.

Verso: December 2, 1942 - USS Oklahoma: Rescue crews are shown here working on the upturned hull of the 29,000-ton battleship USS Oklahoma, which capsised in Pearl Harbor after being blasted by Japanese warplanes.
